review.title: Exploring high-level Perspectives on Self-Configuration Capabilities of Systems
review.abstract: Optimization of product performance repetitively introduces the need to make products adaptive in a more general sense. This more general idea is often captured under the term 'self-configuration'. Despite the importance of such capability, research work on this feature appears isolated by technical domains. It is not easy to tell quickly whether the approaches chosen in different technological domains introduce new ideas or whether the differences just reflect domain idiosyncrasies. For the sake of easy identification of key differences between systems with self-configuring capabilities, I will explore higher level concepts for understanding self-configuration, such as the {\Omega}-units, in order to provide theoretical instruments for connecting different areas of technology and research.

sections.text: s possible to define a configuration like this: c i: = ji (input), f i (input) Equation 4: Conditional plant configurationThe following address ji depends on the input values of the system. The downside of this model lies in the way we can understand decision-making in the self-configuring system: With the help of eq. 4, the environment, the plant and the controller are all involved in "decision-making" by having a parametric function. I do not find it clarifying to have a set of functions that depend on magic properties of the input. Alternatively, the ji () function must classify the input in order to make a decision. If timely decisions are required, ji () can become dependent on past values of itself or on past values of the input (input sequences).

sections.heading: Controller
sections.text: The purpose of the controller configuration is to observe the history of the system, to reconstruct the performance of the system and to redesign the system very expensive.The controller makes tactical decisions at varying degrees of complexity, estimates the advantages and costs of the plant modes (economic assessments) and minimizes risks and costs associated with mode transitions.4.1 TransitionSince the self-configuration and reconfiguration of systems exposed to changing loads, objectives or other conditions, it is important to assess changes (or their absence) in terms of their impact on a dynamic system.An important aspect of this assessment is the relationship between real time and virtual time.Real-time is very important for the operational success of a system.In the specific area of autonomous, self-sustaining systems, synchronization between internal and external events is of paramount importance for the survival chances of the system.

sections.heading: Randomness
sections.text: This type of method is very popular in models with large amounts of nonlinearity and discontinuity. Examples of such methods are simulated by detecting certain forms of genetic algorithms, but on the other hand it also prevents the reproduction of ideal system configurations with heavy "education" that can produce workable configurations even in difficult environments. Mechanisms based on randomness may prevent the system from being repeatedly confronted with the same error that requires certain impasses. On the other hand, it may also prevent the reproduction of ideal system configurations. 4.2.3 Approaches based on MemoryA systems may lack an adequate mechanism for inferencing better configurations when faced with insufficient performance. However, it may simply remember configurations that were not necessarily optimal and that it accidentally found before. Memory can be used to easily restore the stored configurations and then allow the adjustment mechanisms to be optimized.

sections.heading: Configuration
sections.text: The configuration of the systems can be divided between several components. In the following, I will use the notation xxxxx to express how many layers are involved in the systems and how fragmented each layer is.

sections.heading: Activities for Optimized Use of Bandwidth n
sections.text: A similar approach to optimizing the use of bandwidth n. However, the criterion for fragmentation of storage media is different from the plant: The amount of shared information (i.e. the commonality of information) in the configurations can be reduced. However, the rationale behind choosing such a criterion is the assumption that the environment and system state will evolve under some kind of inertia. In this case, configurations that are used in close proximity to time can significantly reduce the small number of bits required to achieve a new configuration, which is the smaller improvement because it is more likely that overwriting of the more common configuration parts is unavoidable (see Figure 44).An architectural model for this approach is shown in Figure 45: 6.4 Compressing the configuration as a means of optimizing bandwidth.

sections.heading: Refactoring
sections.text: "Consider the uppermost behavior in Figure 52: It is a single plant configuration in the input (configuration) space and the plant produces a sequence of configurations in the output (configuration) space. However, given the mission of the workplace, the behavior produced (in this case a cyclic attractor) may be an approximation of an ideal behavior (fine line). If the system wanted to approximate the ideal behavior of the plant but is associated with a non-decompatible plant, then the approximation may be very limited. Imagine that the behavior can only be configured in terms of width, height and velocity. Now, the goal of refactoring is to gain additional configuration possibilities, which could be achieved by searching for piecewise functional substitutions (possibly approximations) of the original monolithic plant behavior as seen in the middle of Figure 52. This could be achieved by splitting the plant into four sections (and rationalization) of the bandwidth.

sections.heading: Behavior
sections.text: In theory, a system can not only be reconfigured for important events, but can also perform more frequent configuration updates, the reconfiguration then becomes an integral part of the behavior of a system. This means that the basic units of any dynamically developing (self) configurable system cannot be understood as its attainable static configurations. Figure 57 represents this idea and also shows bi-modal behavior and possible transitions between two behaviors (mode 1 & 2). Figure 57: Behavior as a history of reconfigurations. A system can have meta configurations that produce characteristic reconfiguration patterns (behaviors). This example shows how the design of mode switches can affect the performance of plants (edy).

sections.heading: Modes
sections.text: It is not possible to clearly serve any hazardous conditions that must be performed with high reliability. The simpler the behavior, the more reliable it can be to re-evaluate the role of modal style, the more it may be that the reconfiguration processes are not considered an integral part of the system behavior (see fig. 47). However, I see other reasons to follow multimodal ("jumpy") reconfigurations: Consider the number 61 for a while, while the system behavior is defined in a hazardous configuration space. It cannot clearly operate from any hazardous conditions that are performed with high reliability.

referenceMentions.context: Self-organization as a phenomenon of structure emergence in dynamical systems has been studied for a long time [1].
Systems with capability to organize themselves are said to be adaptive and robust [2].

Gershenson [2] explains this phenomenon with a two layer process of entropy transport: Entropy increased in lower levels of a system abstraction can result in decreased entropy in higher level system representations.
Yet another explanation is that of dynamic equilibria as were first proposed by Andronov and Pontryagin in [3].

Despite that Gershenson [2] mentions anticipative self-organization, he has only one source to refer to [4] which is a signal simply by the quantity (if compared to references related to adaptive and robustness properties) that anticipative and active organization is not strongly associated to the study of selforganization.
